#Text=Young man," he said, solemnly, going up close to Felix and laying a hand on his shoulder, "speak not lightly of the[57] Divine operations, and restrain unseemly words."

column1: #Text="I ' m not speaking lightly," said Felix.

#Text="If I had not seen that I was making a hog of myself very fast, and that pig-wash, even if I could have got plenty of it, was a poor sort of thing, I should never have looked life fairly in the face to see what was to be done with it.
#Text="No: I heard most of the preachers once, but I never wanted to hear them twice."
#Text=The good Rufus was not without a slight rising of resentment at this young man ' s want of reverence.
#Text=It was not yet plain whether he wanted to hear twice the preacher in Malthouse Yard.
#Text=But the resentful feeling was carefully repressed: a soul in so peculiar a condition must be dealt with delicately.
#Text="And now, may I ask," he said, "what course you mean to take, after hindering your mother from making and selling these drugs?

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=I shall keep my mother as well—nay, better—than she has kept herself.

_	_	_	

#Text=But for a young man so well furnished as you, who can questionless write a good hand and keep books, were it not well to seek some higher situation as clerk or assistant?

column1: #Text=
#Text="Excuse me, Mr.
#Text=Lyon; I ' ve had all that out with my mother, and I may as well save you any trouble by telling you that my mind has been made up about that a long while ago.
#Text=I ' ll take no employment that obliges me to prop up my chin with a high cravat, and wear straps, and pass the livelong day with a set of fellows who spend their spare money on shirt pins.
#Text=That sort of work is really lower than many handicrafts; it only happens to be paid out of proportion.
#Text=That ' s why I set myself to learn the watchmaking trade.
#Text=My father was a weaver first of all.
#Text=It would have been better for him if he had remained a weaver.
#Text=I came home through Lancashire and saw an uncle of mine who is a weaver still.
#Text=I mean to stick to the class I belong to—people who don ' t follow the fashions."

#Text=Why should I want to get into the middle class because I have some learning?

#Text=Oh, yes, your ringed and scented men of the people!

_	_	_	

#Text=Then you have a strong interest in the great political movements of these times?"

column1: #Text=said Mr.
#Text=Lyon, with a perceptible flashing of the eyes.
#Text="I should think so.

#Text=I despise every man who has not—or, having it, doesn ' t try to rouse it in other men.

_	_	_	

#Text=Right, my young friend, right," said the minister, in a deep cordial tone.

column1: #Text=Inevitably his mind was drawn aside from the immediate consideration of Felix Holt ' s spiritual interest by the prospect of political sympathy.
#Text=In those days so many instruments of God ' s cause in the fight for religious and political liberty held creeds that were painfully wrong, and, indeed, irreconcilable with salvation!

#Text="That is my own view, which I maintain in the face of some opposition from[60] brethren who contend that a share in public movements is a hindrance to the closer walk, and that the pulpit is no place for teaching men their duties as members of the commonwealth.
#Text=
#Text="Well, they ' re right enough there," said Felix, with his usual unceremoniousness.

column3:
_	_	_

90-3	8220-8221	!	_	_	_	

#Text=you are of those who hold that a Christian minister should not meddle with public matters in the pulpit?

column1: #Text="Not I, sir," said Felix; "I should say, teach any truth you can, whether it ' s in the Testament or out of it.
#Text=Lyon, pausing in front of Felix.
#Text=He spoke rapidly, as he always did, except when his words were specially weighted with emotion: he overflowed with matter, and in his mind matter was always completely organized into words.

#Text="I speak not on my own behalf, for not only have I no desire that any man should think of me above that which he seeth me to be, but I am aware of much that should make me patient under a disesteem resting even on too hasty a construction.
#Text=
#Text=Here the door opened, and Mr.

#Text=Lyon paused to look around, but seeing only Lyddy with the tea-tray, he went on—
#Text=
#Text=Is, I may say, as a clenched fist that can give blows, but is shut up from receiving and holding aught that is precious—though it were heaven-sent manna."

column1: #Text="I understand you, sir," said Felix, good-humoredly, putting out his hand to the little man, who had come close to him as he delivered the last sentence with sudden emphasis and slowness.
#Text="But I ' m not inclined to clench my fist at you."
#Text="Well, well," said Mr.
#Text=Lyon, shaking the proffered hand, "we shall see more of each other, and I trust shall have much profitable communing.

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=Thank you, I ' ll stay," said Felix, not from any curiosity to see the minister ' s daughter, but from a liking for the society of the minister himself—for his quaint looks and ways, and the transparency of his talk, which gave a charm even to his weakness.

column1: #Text=The daughter was probably some prim Miss, neat, sensible, pious, but all in a small feminine way, in which Felix was no more interested than in Dorcas meetings, biographies of devout women, and that amount of ornamental knitting which was not inconsistent with Non-conforming seriousness.

#Text="I ' m perhaps a little too fond of banging and smashing," he went on: "a phrenologist at Glasgow told me I had large veneration; another man there, who knew me, laughed out and said I was the most blasphemous iconoclast living

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=Yes, yes; I have had my own head explored with somewhat similar results.

column1: #Text=Lyon, who rarely let drop any thread of discourse, "that phrenological science is not irreconcilable with the revealed dispensations.

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=If your truth happens to be such medicine as Holt ' s Pills and Elixir, the less you swallow of it the better," said Felix.

column1: #Text="But truth-vendors and medicine-vendors usually recommend swallowing.

#Text=When a man sees his livelihood in a pill or a proposition, he likes to have orders for the dose, and not curious enquiries.

column1: #Text=That was the signal for Mr.
#Text=Lyon to advance toward the table, raise his right hand, and ask a blessing at sufficient length for Esther to[63] glance at the visitor again.
#Text=There seemed to be no danger of his looking at her: he was observing her father.
#Text=She had time to remark that he was a peculiar looking person, but not insignificant, which was the quality that most hopelessly consigned a man to perdition.
#Text=He was massively built.
#Text=The striking points in his face were large clear gray eyes and full lips.
#Text="Will you draw up to the table, Mr.
#Text=said Felix, "I beg your pardon."
#Text=Esther had already started up, and with wonderful quickness had picked up half the small rolling things while Felix was lifting the basket and the book.
#Text=This last had opened, and had its leaves crushed in falling; and, with the instinct of a bookish man, he saw nothing more pressing to be done than to flatten the corners of the leaves.
#Text="Byron ' s Poems!"
#Text=he said, in a tone of disgust, while Esther was recovering all the other articles. " ' The Dream ' —he ' d better have been asleep and snoring.
